Project Title: Anvari-BioSafety Protocol 05082019
Project Description: We construct optical nano-particles containing near infrared dyes such as indocyanine green. The encapsulating material can be a polymer (polyallyl(amine) hydrochloride amine), proteins derived from the capsid of the plant-infecting brome mosaic virus, or constructs derived from human, mouse, or bovine erythrocytes. We investigate the ability of these constructs in cell imaging, and photo-destruction of cells. We evaluate the interaction of these particles with various cell lines to study cytotoxicity and examine their targeting potentials. These cells are human embryonic kidney cells, human endothelial cells, normal and cancerous human bronchial epithelial and cervical epithelial cells, human ovarian and breast cancer cells. We are also interested in the interaction of our various types of our constructs with cells of the reticuloendothelial system (RES) to understand the effects of the constructs materials on the resulting biodistribution. For these studies, we use human blood monocytes, human hepatocytes, human spleen macrophages, mouse kupffer cells, and mouse spleen macrophages, which are important constituents of the RES system.
Project Objectives: (1) Optical imaging of cells with and without incubation with various constructs. (2) Laser irradiation of cells incubated by with and without various constructs.
Special Equipment Desc: hoods, gloves, lab coat, safety glasses and incubator, laser safety goggles

All biohazard bags will be double-bagged when full, or as needed (not less than weekly), placed in a leak proof plastic bin, and autoclaved for 1 hr at 121 degrees Celsius and 15 psi. Contaminated sharps are disposed in the sharps containers that remain inside the BSC. All biohazard bags will be transported to the red biohazard bins in MSE 283 via cart and will be picked up by EH&S

Project Title: Research on soil, dust, slugs, and sterile plant and animal tissue extracts
Project Description: We are investigating the soil, plant and animal microbiome in general. In particular, we are working with soils and dusts with no known pathogens, collected in US field locations, non-exotic terrestrial gastropods with no known pathogens, sterile DNA extracts from native and exotic plants and soils. The purpose is to characterize how plants mediate soil microbiomes and vice versa, as well as to understand what microorganisms disperse via dust. We are also working with DNA extracts and the supernatant of the lung BAL (bronchioalveolar lavage) from mice, born and raised under laboratory conditions. We are exposing the mice in a chamber in Dr. Lo's lab to dust from regions of CA to look for the lung microbiome responses. The purpose is to characterize how exposure to dust changes the lung microbiome of the mice.
Project Objectives: The goals are to understand the soil, plant and animal microbiome. Specifically, to understand how soil microorganisms may be transported from one location to another using plants, animals and wind-borne dust as vectors, as well as the impact of soil microbial diversity on the ecosystem functions the soil provides. Another specific objective is the characterize the interaction between lung inflammatory response and microbiome.
Special Equipment Desc: BSC, Fume Hood, PPE, and others

Project Title: Cloud Condensation Nuclei Studies with MS2 Bacteriophage
Project Description: Understanding the droplet forming potential of MS2 Bacteriophage. MS2 will be exposed to high supersaturation conditions and subsequently counted if grown to droplet sizes.
Project Objectives: MS@ will be aerosolized and captured within the Cloud condensation chamber. Droplets will be counted.

Project Title: Fine-Scale Recombination Rate Variation in Anopheles gambiae (NIAID), Gene Editing in Plutella xylostella (BASF/CARA), SW Vector-Borne Disease Regional Center of Excellence (CDC), Immune priming the piRNA pathway for arboviral resistance in Aedes aegypti (NIAID), Establishing a CRISPR-based gene drive system for controlling the haplodiploid agricultural pest, the whitefly B. tabaci (BARD to LL Walling and PWA), Genome Edited Whiteflies for the Future of Agriculture (DARPA to LLW/PWA)
Funding: National Institutes of Health, National Science Foundation/BARD, Centers for Disease Control, BASF, California Department of Agriculture, WM Keck Foundation.
Project Description: The amendment notes the relocation of mosquitoes from 135 to 236 and 238 and the use of 234 for whiteflies. We undertake research aimed at developing genetic and chemical based insect pest control strategies for medically and agriculturally important insect species. The mosquito species we focus on are the yellow fever mosquito Aedes aegypti, the southern house mosquito, Culex pipiens quinquefasciatus, the African malaria mosquito Anopheles coluzzii, and the southern asian malaria mosquito Anopheles stephensi. Our approaches are to develop gene tagging strategies that identify genes expressed in tissues involved in pathogen transmission and to explore how a small RNA pathway in Aedes and Culex provides immunity to pathogenic mosquito viruses. Our aim here is to harness this response so it provides mosquitoes immunity to human pathogenic viruses transmitted by mosquitoes. For Lepidoptera we develop mutants with easily scored phenotypes. In addition we use CRISPR mutagenesis to explore some aspects of insecticide resistance. For the Hemiptera we are developing genetic methods in order to identify genetic and biochemical pathways that will form the basis of new pest control strategies.
Project Objectives: We seek to genetically alter pest insect species in order to control them and the damage they exact upon human welfare either through vectoring human pathogens or by negatively impacting agriculture. To do this we employ transpositional recombination, site-specific recombination and CRISPR/Cas-mediated genome editing, each of which can generate genetically modified insects. Specifically, weseek to develop mosquitoes that are incapable of transmitting human disease. To do this we need to develop genetic strategies for mosquitoes that can deliver suitable genes that can then spread through mosquito populations. We seek to develop Lepidoptera pests that are tagged with new and novel screenable genetic markers and have desired mutations in genes involved in insecticide resistance and in host plant feeding. We seek to develop Hemiptera pests that: are tagged with new and novel screenable genetic markers. have mutations which affect their ability to feed on planet hosts. are modified to replace wild type populations and in doing so replace field populations with populations carrying desired traits. All approaches with all of the species we study also increase our knowledge of basic science underpinning how these species maintain their pestiferous properties.
Special Equipment Desc: We will obtain the DENV2 Jamaica strain of dengue from either the CDC MR4 facility or from colleagues in the US who have cultured it. We will culture this in Aedes albopictus cell culture under BSL2 conditions in my lab in 2237 Genomics and then prepare viral extracts for infection of Aedes aegypti mosquitoes through blood feeding of infected bovine blood. This infection, rearing and analysis of infected mosquitoes will be performed under ACL3 conditions in the IQF. Infected and control mosquitoes will be reared inside perspex cages with mesh and sleeves. This ACL3 insectary suite will be renovated in 2018/19. In separate experiments dealing the whitefly Bemisia tabaci, genetically edited whitefly that contain gene drive systems will be reared in the new ACL3 suite, specifically in cages in the greenhouse attached to it. These strains will be created in the Atkinson laboratory in 2237 Genomics and reared as immobile nymphs in the ACL2 insectary within it. They will be transported in double sealed plastic containers to the IQF before emergence.

Project Title: Analysis of chromosome segregation in yeast
Project Description: Our work is focused on how a protein modification called SUMO modification regulates mitotic chromosome segregation in the budding yeast S. cerevisiae. Our hypothesis is that there are proteins that are regulated by SUMO that contribute to accurate chromosome segregation. The purpose of our work is to identify these proteins and determine how SUMO regulates their function.
Project Objectives: There are three specific aims 1) Determine the mechanism connecting SUMO modificatin to centromere integrity. 2) Determine how SUMO modification regulates cohesion at centromeres. 3) Determine the mechanism connecting Top2 SUMO modification to centromere cohesion. All three aims utilize recombinant DNA techniques and Escherichia coli and Saccharomyces cerevisiae as experimental biological organisms.

Project Title: (4) CA-R*-BPS-5436-H: Signal and Response Mechanisms that Regulate Tolerance to Abiotic Stresses in Plants
Project Description: The purpose of this research is to determine the mechanisms of signal transduction and gene regulation that underlie plant response to non-optimal growth conditions. The studies are aimed at elucidation of cellular mechanisms of signal transduction and gene regulation that mediate changes in physiology and development. The project includes development of plants that are better able to survive abiotic stress. The project outcome provides information on fundamental aspects of cell biology that may have relevance to agriculture, plant biotechnology or human health.
Project Objectives: Recombinant bacterial strains and plants are produced for specific purposes. Recombinant bacteria are used for gene cloning. Recombinant plants are used to address specific questions about plant biology. CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing in rice, maize and Arabidopsis to alter promoters, protein coding regions, RNA regulatory elements and to knock-out gene function, of one or multiple related genes. As is the standard practice for these plants, the editing machinery will be delivered on a T-DNA via agrobacterium. These edited plants will be used to address specific questions about plant biology. we address fundamental questions about development and response to abiotic stress. Genome editing will be performed to make stable (heritable gene mutations and also to perform cell-specific mutations, if feasible (non-heritable). We will also use genome edited lines produced by a collaborator at Iowa State University (Bing Yang) in a NSF funded project.
Special Equipment Desc: The CDC guidelines are followed for procedures involving recombinant bacterial. Transgenic plant material is limited to growth chambers and greenhouses approved for growth of transgenic plants. All recombinant material is autoclaved before disposal.

Project Title: Cloning and overexpressing eubacterial factors and isolating ribosomes and RNA polymerase from E. coli and T.thermophilus
Project Description: The project investigates an heretofore not described regulation of the flow of genetic information from DNA to protein in bacteria.
Project Objectives: 1.Clone and overexpress transcription and translation factors from various bacteria. 2. Isolate ribosomes and RNA polymerase from T.thermophilus and various strains of E. coli.

Project Title: Functional Genomics of Fungi
Funding: National Institutes of Health National Science Foundation Department of Energy
Project Description: We are studying genes that are important for growth, development and pathogenesis in filamentous fungi. Most of our work involves the nonpathogenic model filamentous fungus Neurospora crassa. We are also using strains of the plant pathogen Fusarium oxysporum to study the role of small RNAs in immunity in tomato plants and of the saprobe Chaetomium thermophilum to study regulation of cellulase secretion.

N. crassa, F. oxysporum and C. thermophilum integrating vectors include those conferring hygromycin resistance (Aspergillus nidulans trpC promoter), BASTA resistance (A. nidulans trpC promoter ) and nourseothricin resistance (A. nidulans gpdA promoter). Recipients for transformation will be various N. crassa, F. oxysporum, C. thermophilum, S. cerevisiae and E. coli strains. N. crassa strains will be recipients for vectors conferring his-3 prototrophy (N. crassa gene) on N. crassa. S. cerevisiae vectors (2-micron or centromere) include those conferring ura-3, trp-1 or leu-2 prototrophy or resistance to hygromycin for use in the two-hybrid assay or recombinational cloning of gene fragments. Tomato plants will be inoculated with F. oxysporum and incubated in a plant growth chamber. Tomatoes or other fruits will be inoculated with F. oxysporum, placed in containers and grown in an incubator in the laboratory. N. crassa, C. thermophilum, S. cerevisiae, E. coli, F. oxysporum cultures and F. oxysporum-infected plant material will be autoclaved prior to disposal. Pots and soil used for growth of plants infected with F. oxysporum will be autoclaved. Irrigation water and containers will be decontaminated using bleach. Project Title: Molecules of activated microglia
Project Description: Microglia are the tissue macrophage of the brain and spinal cord. Their activation contributes to several types of neurological disorders. Our studies are aimed at identifying potential points of therapeutic intervention by indentifying specific molecules expressed by microglia. We then test the function of these molecules by artificially increasing and "knocking'down" the expression of specific molecules. Common methods designed to alter expression of molecules within cells are not effective in microglia and many other types of macrophages. Therefore, we use replication incompetent lentiviral vectors to introduce our overexpression or knock-down molecules into microglia.
Project Objectives: To manipulate microglial, macrophage and immune clle gene expression and test for subsequent changes in immune phenotype and function. My lab has identified molecules preferentially expressed in murine microglia (brain macrophages) and/or hematogenously-derived macrophages. The function of these molecules is unknown. Using bioinformatic analysis, we have identified ITIM and ITAM signaling motifs. We do not know if they are active.

Project Title: Light signaling in plants
Project Description: The long-term goal of the PI's project is to understand how plants respond to changes in their light environment. In particular, the project utilizes Arabidopsis thaliana as the genetic model and a combination of molecular genetics, biochemical, and genomic approaches to investigate the signaling mechanism by which the red/far-red photoreceptors, the phytochromes, control plant growth and development.
Project Objectives: 1. Construction of recombinant DNA molecules to clone or subclone genes and genomic DNAs in E. coli and yeast. 2. Generation of transgenic Arabidopsis lines expressing tagged proteins to study the function and subcellular localization of light signaling molecules in plants.

Project Description: We strive to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying cell fate specification in plant development. We study how small RNAs are synthesized and degraded in the cell, how they move between cells, and how they function in gene regulation and in development. We investigate the mechanisms of RNA modifications. We study Arabidopsis, rice, tobacco, soybean, and maize plants. Project Title: Neurobiological mechanisms of learning and memory
Project Description: The aim of these research projects is to understand the neurobiological mechanisms of how the brain works for learning and memory. To this end, we will use mouse models of fear conditioning and extinction, models for studying the neural mechanisms of associative learning and memory. In these projects, we will investigate mechanisms of the formation and extinction of fear memory at the cellular and neural circuit level. We will also investigate how these processes are regulated by neuromodulatory systems for adaptive fear responses. To this end, we will use a combination of optogenetic, electrophysiological, and behavioral approaches in mouse models. Long-term goal of this research project is to develop pharmacological and optogenetic methods to facilitate extinction of maladaptive fear memory by controlling neuromodulatory systems or inducing neuroplasticity in fear extinction circuitry. Results from these studies would contribute to a deeper mechanistic understanding of fear learning and memory, which could lead to identifying new therapeutic targets for enhancing the extinction of pathological fear memories in fear-related disorders including post-traumatic stress disorder.
Project Objectives: We will use viral vectors to deliver genes to a specific population of neurons in the mouse brain in order to control the activity of these neurons and/or label them. These replication-incompetent viral vectors are based on adeno-associated virus, lentivirus, herpes simplex virus type 1, rabies virus or canine adenovirus. These packaged viral vectors will be purchased from vector core facilities at other institutions (e.g. University of North Carolina). A small volume of solution containing high-titer virus (less than 1 microlitter) will be microinjected into the intended areas of the mouse brain. Viruses will locally infect neurons or glial cells in these areas, which induces the expression of gene(s) coding fluorescent proteins (e,g, GFP, mCherry), photosensitive opsins (e,g, channelrhodopsin, archaerhodopsin), modified acetylcholine receptors (DREADDs) and/or recombinases (e,g, cre). However, the transgene does not encode either a potentially tumorigenic gene product or a toxin molecule. These viruses do not cause systemic infection in mice or leave the animal after microinfused into the brain.

Project Title: Genetic Variation in Crop Plant Germplasm
Funding: Hatch Project, NSF, USAID, USDA, BMGF, CGIAR
Project Description: My research is in Agricultural Plant Genomics. My research goals are unified by the question, "What are the fundamental biochemical processes within which there exists genetic diversity related to tolerance of abiotic stresses such as low temperature, drought, and salinity and resistance to pests and pathogens?" The plants that I study using rDNA molecules are cowpea and barley. The work includes the use of fragments of the barley and cowpea genomes, as well as study of these fragments to infer the function of the proteins they encode and their relationship to plant traits. The presence of these fragments in a bacterial host provides a convenient source of DNA molecules to enable these studies. All of the work with these molecules is under the umbrella of my Hatch project.
Project Objectives: Recombinant DNA methods have been used to produced bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) clones of barley and cowpea, which will be used to define the specific genes or positions in a DNA molecule that are responsible for traits that have been observed at the whole plant level. In cowpea a goal is to identify a gene controlling pigment production in sepals, pods and seed coats. Other genes controlling chilling tolerance, heat tolerance, drought tolerance, and resistance to several insects, fungi and viruses are also possible topics. In barley a goal is to explore environmentally induced unequal recombination in a region containing stress-induced genes known as dehydrins.

Project Title: Mechanisms of feeding behavior regulation (NSF). Functional analysis of insect taste receptors (NIH). Investigation of meal destination in Aedes aegypti (NIH). Allies of searching and seeking insects to detect threats (DARPA)
Project Description: We are interested in molecular, sensory and circuit functions of the insect taste system and its interactions with behavior and physiology. The taste system detects non-volatile environmental chemicals that signal the presence of food, toxins, mating partners, or egg-laying sites. Chemicals are detected by membrane proteins encoded by members of various receptor families (Gustatory receptor (Gr), Inotropic receptor (Ir), Pickpocket (Ppk), Transient Receptor Potential (Trp), Odorant receptor (Or)), which are expressed in dendrites of neurons located in taste organs. Axons of chemosensory neurons project to regions in the brain and thoracic ganglia, where they make their first synaptic connections. We will address some fundamental problems in insect chemosensory systems and neuroscience using Drosophila melanogaster and three mosquito species, Anopheles gambiae, Aedes aegypti, Culex quinquefasciatus, as experimental models. Specifically, we will investigate 1) how taste receptors recognize specific compounds, 2) how sensory neurons respond to specific chemicals, 3) how sensory neurons connect with higher order neurons at an anatomical and functional level, 4) how activation of taste circuits gives rise to specific behaviors and physiological outcomes, and 5) how taste circuits and behaviors are modulated by factors such as experience, context and internal state. We will also use various Drosophila species to study the evolution of taste receptor genes and their roles in determining variation in feeding preference across species. We will address these questions in insect models with a multidisciplinary approach using molecular, genetic, electrophysiological, behavioral and imaging techniques. Transgenic approaches will be restricted to the genetic model Drosophila melanogaster, the common housefly Musca domestica, and Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. For functional studies in flies and mosquitoes we will use RNAi and genome-editing strategies such as CRISPR. We will apply the principles gleaned from studies with Drosophila to insects of commercial and health relevance, including the named mosquito disease vectors and nuisance pest Musca domestica. We are also interested in developing two models: a Drosophila in vivo functional expression system to characterize taste receptors from vertebrates including humans, and a genetically engineered housefly to search and seek targeted chemicals in the environment. Transgenic mosquitoes will be reared in the INQ (Room 156). Batches of mosquitoes will be transported to Genomics in vials or cages held in secondary containers held in cardboard boxes labeled with biohazard symbols, and maintained in Room 2210. Transgenic houseflies will be reared, maintained and tested for behavior in Genomics 2210. This room has a screen at the entrance and an electric racquet to kill escapees. Vials with one or few insects will be carried in secondary containers to Room 2223A or 2207B for imaging or electrophysiology experiments.

Project Title: FTIR Studies of Photosynthetic Oxygen Production. UCR Agricultural Station Project (CA-R*-BCH-7149-H), entitled "Mechanism of Light-Induced Damage associated with Oxygen Production in Photosystem II"
Funding: UCR Agricultural Experiment Station, DOE (Office of Basic Energy Sciences)
Project Description: The project's overall goal is to elucidate the molecular mechanism of photosynthetic O2 production. This process is catalyzed by the Mn4CaO5 cluster in Photosystem II and provides nearly our entire supply of atmospheric oxygen. The Mn4CaO5 cluster accumulates oxidizing equivalents in response to light-driven photochemical events within Photosystem II and then oxidizes two molecules of water to oxygen in the final step of a five-step cycle. Water oxidation is an extremely difficult chemical reaction, both thermodynamically and kinetically, yet the Mn4Ca cluster catalyzes this reaction far more efficiently than any synthetic catalyst. The reason is that nature carefully designed the protein environment of the Mn4CaO5 cluster. This environment controls the cluster's reactivity at each step in the catalytic cycle by carefully choreographing the proton and electron transfer reactions associated with water oxidation and by carefully managing both substrate (water) access and proton egress. The project's primary goal is to identify the amino acid residues that are responsible for this control and to determine the role of each. This information is crucial to understanding the mechanism of O2 production in Photosystem II and will complement information that is being obtained from X-ray crystallography. The projects primary investigative tool is infrared (IR) spectroscopy. The projects primary aims are to further delineate the dominant water access and proton egress pathways that link the Mn4CaO5 cluster with the thylakoid lumen and to characterize the influence of specific residues on the water molecules that serve as substrate or as participants in the networks of hydrogen bonds that make up the water access and proton egress pathways. Both FTIR difference spectroscopy and time-resolved IR spectroscopy are being conducted with mutant Photosystem II core complexes representing residues identified crystallographically or computationally as potentially participating in networks of hydrogen bonds or otherwise interacting with the Mn4CaO5 cluster and the water molecules in its immediate environment. Identifying these residues and further delineating the networks of hydrogen bonds that form water access and proton egress channels will improve our understanding of the dynamic mechanism of water oxidation by the Mn4CaO5 catalyst in PSII and will provide insight into the design of new generations of synthetic catalysts that convert sunlight into useful forms of storable energy.
Project Objectives: The environment of the manganese cluster in Photosystem II is made up of amino acid residues from two specific polypeptide chains. To determine the role of a specific residue (e.g., Aspartate-170 of the D1 polypeptide), this residue is changed (e.g., Aspartate-170 is changed to Histidine) by site-directed mutagenesis of the corresponding gene. The mutation-bearing Photosystem II complexes are purified and characterized spectroscopically. We are also planning to overexpress the dorC gene (encoding a membrane-associated pentaheme protein) of the photosynthetic bacterium Rhodobacter sphaeroides in a strain of this organism that has been engineered for the overexpression of membrane proteins.

Project Title: The role of fatty acid- and retinol-binding proteins in parasitic nematode infections
Project Description: The purpose of the project is to determine the effects of nematode venom toxins. To do this, we will be injecting flies with the purified venom toxins. To help us understand the role of the toxins in the infection, we will be injecting flies that are already sick with one of a number of bacterial pathogens: E. coli, Listeria monocytogenes, Salmonella typhimurium, Mycobacterium marinum, Staphylococcus aureus, and Streptoccus pneumoniae. We will use these pathogens to determine how the infection dynamics change when the venom toxins are introduced into this model. At first we will be injecting a mix of purified secreted toxins from the insect-parasitic nematodes. Once we examine the properties of the mix as a whole, we may want to follow up on individual proteins from the toxin mix. To do this we would need to transfect E. coli with the gene of interest and purify recombinant toxin protein from E. coli to then inject into flies infected with one of the pathogens listed above. Infection dynamics will be studied by evaluating bacterial growth and fly survival.
Project Objectives: What are the objectives of the work with biohazardous materials: Determine the effect of fatty acid- and retinol-binding (FAR) toxins using an in vivo infection model. To better understand the role of secreted FAR proteins during parasitic nematode infections, we will utilize a Drosophila melanogaster infection model. The fly is an excellent model for human diseases and has conserved orthologs with >60% of single human disease genes. The innate immune pathways are also largely conserved between flies and humans. Infecting flies with different pathogens coupled with secreted nematode proteins will allow us to determine the specificity of the proteins as immune modulators. Hosts will be infected with a sub lethal dose of bacteria along with FAR toxins and the course of infection will be followed. We may also need to inject the flies with recombinant secreted FAR toxins, but we are using insect-parasitic nematodes so there is no health hazard with this part of the work. We will identify alterations to the infection outcome and the host immune response using health, bacterial growth, and immune reactivity (phagocytosis, anti-microbial peptide induction, and melanization). As we follow up on individual components of the toxic nematode secretions (insect-specific toxins), we will want to focus more in depth on certain individual toxins. To do that we will need to purify recombinant toxin proteins from transformed E. coli, and then inject those proteins into flies infected with bacteria. In terms of parasitic nematodes, we will be extracting nucleic acid for amplification and sequencing.
Special Equipment Desc: Negative pressure rooms, mesh or grating on the air ducts, double door (one solid, one screen), air curtain on door, all to prevent fly escape.

Project Title: The role and control of the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase 1 gene family incucumber virus defense. CRISPR/Cas9-Mediated Viral Interference in Plants. Function and mechanism of the mammalian RNAi response to virus infection
Funding: NIH. US-Israel Binational Agricultural Research & Development Fund (BARD). King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST) of Saudi Arabia
Project Description: Characterization of RNA interference (RNAi) as an antiviral defense mechanism in plants, mice and in cultured human cells. identification and mechanism analysis of the host genes in the defense pathway and of the viral suppressors of the plant and animal antiviral response. determine if a new vaccine strategy against animal viral pathogens could be developed according to the RNAi-mediated antiviral immunity. and application of these mechanistic insights in the control of plant viral diseases.
Project Objectives: Infectious cDNA clones of Coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3), Dengue virus serotype 2 and 4 are used to make the low/non virulent RNAi suppressor-deletion mutants as vaccine candidate strains for mouse challenges. Plasmid vectors based the backbones of Adeno-associated virus and Murine leukemia virus are for the expression of specific human genes (such as Argonaute and Dicer proteins) or reporter (such as GFP or luciferase) in cultured mammalian cells or mice. Vaccine strains of influenza A viruses and dengue viruses are used to determine the role of RNAi and of viral suppressors of RNA silencing during infection. The negative-strand RNA viruses Vesicular stomatitis virus and Sendai virus will be used for cell culture and mouse infection to the role of RNAi during mammalian infection. In addition, cucumber mosaic virus, citrus tristeza virus, turnip yellow mosaic virus, tomato yellow leaf curl virus and related plant viruses as well as infectious cDNA clones of these viruses will be used.
Special Equipment Desc: The viruses used frequently in the projects include Flock house virus, cricket paralysis virus, Orsay virus or Nodamura virus and none is known to infect human. However, working with the vaccine strains of influenza A viruses, the AAV- and MLV-based viral particles, Dengue viruses, coxsackievirus B3, vesicular stomatitis virus and Sendai virus requires the use of biosafety cabinets and to wear lab coat and gloves. A hand-washing sink has been installed in the tissue culture room.
Medical Surveillance: No other specific medical screening or surveillance is needed since the projects do not involve the use of human blood (or its products), human primary cells or other human specimens.

Project Title: Biochemical analysis of deidentified whole blood, plasma, and intestinal biopsies from healthy humans, and use non-replicating viral vectors to study gut-brain physiology in mice
Project Description: This project involves the analysis of our UCR and non-UCR collaborator's deidentified whole blood and plasma samples from healthy humans. We will evaluate levels of lipids in whole blood and plasma from subjects with the goal of observing fluctuations depending upon feeding status. In addition, we will use non-replicating viral vectors, injected into the upper small intestine and brain of mice, to identify gut-brian physiology. Virus will induce expression of proteins that can be activated and in turn, activate specific neural pathways.
Project Objectives: We aim to evaluate fluctuations in circulating lipids as they relate to feeding status (e.g.,hungry/satiated). The use of viral vectors will allow for the examination of gut-brain feeding circuits and cross-talk between the gut and brain.
Special Equipment Desc: Biosafety cabinet, anti-spill caps for centrifuge, secondary containers for all samples.

Project Title: Chromosomal Mechanisms in Environmental Carcinogenesis V
Project Description: Our research involves measuring genetic changes in cells using various molecular cytogenetic techniques including fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) which uses DNA probes to detect changes in chromosome number and the structure of large chromosomal regions in mammalian cells. In these studies, we generate chromosome-specific DNA probes by amplifying highly repetitive or unique sequences in human, rat or mouse DNA using PCR with general primers or primers specific for the sequences of interest. In many cases, modified bases are incorporated into PCR-generated probes either directly or through nick translation. These probes are then used for FISH analyses. In other cases, the PCR-amplified DNA may be inserted into a plasmid vector and transformed into chemically competent E. coli (such as TOP10 cells from Invitrogen). Colonies containing positive transformants are grown up and the plasmid DNA isolated. The insert and or the plasmid is then labeled for FISH using PCR, random priming or nick translation techniques. Occasionally, we obtain plasmids, bacteria containing plasmids or yeast containing artificial chromosomes from repositories or other investigators which are used to generate chromosome-specific probes for FISH.
Project Objectives: Our goal is to detect chromosomal alterations occurring in mammalian cells. These may occur spontaneously or as the result of exposure to genotoxic agents.

Project Title: NSF: Genome-wide impact of mPing transposition on rice phenotypic diversity HHMI: SALSA Keck: NEW ACTIVE TRANSPOSABLE ELEMENTS FOR MOSQUITO GENETICS USDA NIFA-Dynamic Genome/USDA Summer Scholars USDA NIFA: Immersion for Community College Students to UCR USDA-Hatch: Transposable Elements as drivers of gene and genome evolution
Funding: Howard Hughes Medical Institute, National Science Foundation, W. M. Keck Foundation, USDA
Project Description: The purpose of this project is to identify and characterize a type genetic element called a transposable element (jumping gene in popular literature). These elements move about the genome and create biological diversity in a species. We identify these elements using a combination of computer searches and wet-bench experiments. By studying these elements we may be able to use these elements to improve food crops or open new avenues to control mosquitos. We also characterize the genome of the Fairchild Mandarin and other plants studied by UCR professors and clone genes and promoters of classes of genes found in the circadian clock, host-pathogen interaction and fruit quality. We are studying genes that are important for growth, development, cell signaling and cellulose degradation in the nonpathogenic filamentous fungus and model organism Neurospora crassa in a project with UCR Professor Kathy Borkovich.
Project Objectives: Specifically new and interesting transposable elements will be cloned from plants and mosquitos into bacterial and yeast plasmid vectors. The cloned elements will be studied in yeast to identify elements that should be pursued as potential vectors for the host organism. Existing transgenic Arabidopsis plants are used in the class to demonstrate the requirements for transposable elements excision. Elements found to be active in yeast may be transformed into Arabidosis to further test their function. We will use reporter systems to test promoter activity requiring transformation of tobacco and citrus cultures with Agrobacterium. Genetic elements will be cloned into E. coli for sequencing and propagation of plasmid DNA. With Dr. Kathy Borkovich, we will use Escherichia coli vectors conferring resistance to ampicillin or chloramphenicol for cloning of Neurospora crassa DNA. N. crassa integrating vectors include those conferring hygromycin resistance (Aspergillus nidulans trpC promoter), BASTA resistance (A. nidulans trpC promoter ) and nourseothricin resistance (A. nidulans gpdA promoter). Recipients for transformation will be various N. crassa, S. cerevisiae and E. coli strains. N. crassa strains will be recipients for vectors conferring his-3 prototrophy (N. crassa gene) on N. crassa. S. cerevisiae vectors (2-micron or centromere-containing) include those conferring ura-3, trp-1 or leu-2 prototrophy for use in the two-hybrid assay or recombinational cloning of N. crassa gene fragments. Genes will include those involved in growth and development in N. crassa. All transfers/inoculations of N. crassa and S. cerevisiae will take place in a Laminar Airflow Workstation. N. crassa, S. cerevisiae and E. coli cultures will be autoclaved prior to disposal.
Special Equipment Desc: Transformed plants will be transferred to the professor's lab for proper growth conditions and containment. No transformed plants will be allowed to flower in the rooms listed on this application. Plants will be transferred according to the controls listed in the respective professor's approved BUA. All engineered strains will be autoclaved prior to disposal. Potential environmental or health hazards are considered minimal. Neurospora crassa, Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Escherichia coli are not plant pathogens. Certain strains of S. cerevisiae (not used in these experiments) have nominal impact as animal pathogens (and only in immunocompromised hosts). The strains of E. coli used are heavily mutated for genetic engineering approaches and considered minimal risk as animal pathogens.
Medical Surveillance: Not sure of LD50 of hygromycin B in humans. However, this drug is treated as toxic in the laboratory. It is dispensed in the biosafety cabinet using double-gloves and all transfer implements and media are immediately autoclaved after use. Two laminar flow hoods are already in the laboratory and will be used at all times when handling cultures of N. crassa. Gloves and required PPE will also be worn by personnel when handling cultures of E. coli, S. cerevisiae and N. crassa.

Project Title: Protein and enzyme engineering
Funding: National Science Foundation Engineering Division (NSF CBET), Air Force Office of Scientific Research (AFOSR), Army Office of Research (ARO), and Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA),
Project Description: This project involves the use of bacteria (E. coli K12 and host vector systems) to produce proteins and enzymes of interest. Mutations and alterations to plasmid DNA encoding the proteins and enzymes of interests will be made and transformed in the expression bacteria.
Project Objectives: This work aims to improve the catalytic performance of enzymes for the production of biofuels, commodity chemicals, and high-value chemicals and pharmaceuticals as well as the enzymes for the degradation of such chemicals. For example, one goal of this work funded by the ARO is to produce alcohol and aldehyde dehyrogrenase enzymes for the oxidation of alcohol fuels in bio-fuel cell applications. Point mutations will be made to the relevant enzymes to 1) improve catalytic performance, 2) facilitate enzyme immobilization, and 3) improve enzyme stability. Another example, funded by DTRA, is to produce enzyme in high catalytic efficiency for the degradation of organophosphate compounds and their hydrolysis products.

Project Title: Engineering microorganisms to produce renewable chemicals
Project Description: In this work we will engineering standard laboratory strains of bacteria (E.coli, pseudomonads (BSL1 strains only. e.g., P. chlororaphis and P. fluorescens) and yeast (S. cerevisisae, K. marxianus, Y. lypolitica, W. anomalus) to produce high value and commodity chemicals such as ethyl acetate, ethanol, butanol, ester flavor compounds, phenazines, and pharmaceutical precursors. Using protein and metabolic engineering techniques the enzymes of the desired pathway will be overexpressed in the desired microorganism. Our primary focus in these projects is the engineering and organization of metabolic pathways.
Project Objectives: Standard laboratory strains of bacteria (e.g., E. coli K12 and P. chlororaphis ATCC 13985), and yeast (S. cerevisisae, K. marxianus, Y. lypolitica, W. anomalus) will be genetically modified to control and engineer cellular functions. E.coli will be used to facilitate DNA cloning and molecular biology work. The overall goal of our work is to study and engineering biochemical and protein synthesis in the targeted organisms. Specific objectives of the work include: 1) Genome editing, including the creation of gene deletions and insertions, the insertion of heterologous expression cassettes, and point mutations to target genes. Manipulations to the genome are made by CRISPR-Cas9 (or similar) technology, by transformation of homologous recombination donor DNA, and by transformation of linear DNA that is randomly incorporated through illegitimate recombination. 2) Transcriptional regulation, gene knockdown, and gene activation. Techniques such as CRISPR interference (CRISPRi), CRISPR activation (CRISPRa), and promoter engineering will be used to regulate gene expression from an organisms' genome. Here, suitable recombinant DNA will be transformed into the target organism to transiently manipulate gene expression. 3) Episomal gene expression. Plasmid DNA encoding native or heterologous genes will be transformed into the target organism to test for expression and function. 4) Transcriptional analysis. Characterization of wild type and engineered organisms will be conducted by isolating and sequencing RNA. Sequencing and analysis techniques include next-generation sequences as well as quantitative RT-PCR.
Special Equipment Desc: lab coats. gloves. eye protection. when necessary biosafety hoods.

Project Title: CNS immune response to Toxoplasma gondii
Project Description: The research focuses on the immune response in the brain following Toxoplasma infection. The control of this immune response is very important - too little and the parasite multiplies killing host cells, too much can cause potentially damaging CNS inflammation. Although Toxoplasma is a highly common human infection - it rarely causes pathology thus the immune response is normally controlled very well in the brain. It is the mechanism of this control that the lab aims to study.
Project Objectives: Toxoplasma gondii is a protozoan parasite. Maintenance of the parasite will require in vitro culture in fibroblasts and occasionally passaging in vivo in mice. For experiments, parasites will be used to infect mice along with in vitro addition to cells and the resulting immune response measured.
Special Equipment Desc: full PPE should be used when working on the animals to prevent exposure to allergens: gloves, masks, gowns, footwear, hair coverings. Toxoplasma gondii is considered BSL2 and should be dealt with in biosafety hood. In addition all surfaces will be decontaimanted using 70% ethanol and live culutes bleached before disposal and autoclaving.
Medical Surveillance: Antibody titering will be conducted on a yearly basis for all lab members. Any pregnant or immune compromised individuals will not be allowed to work with the parasite. All potential lab members in particular women of child bearing age will be warned of the dangers of working with Toxoplasma.

Project Title: The roles of RNA binding proteins in mammals
Project Description: Many human neurological diseases and disorders of the muscular system are caused by errors in the regulation of a process called alternative pre-mRNA splicing and mRNA decay. These include frontotemporal dementia, spinal muscular atrophy, some forms of autism, and various muscular dystrophies. We specifically study how alternative splicing and mRNA decay is regulated in the nervous system and the protein molecules that control it. These molecules are usually RNA binding proteins whose mutations have been implicated in various diseases. To understand how the processes are mis-regulated in diseases, one needs to first understand how they function in the normal organism and cells. We applied multidisciplinary techniques, including mouse genetics, functional genomics, informatics, neuroscience, molecular biology and cellular biology to understand how the RNA binding proteins recognize RNA, interact with one another, control RNA processing, affect cellular activities, brain development and functions. The understanding gained from these studies will be an essential first step in the development of treatments for a variety of human disorders.
Project Objectives: We generate recombinant DNA and viruses to induce or deplete gene expression in cells. We use bacteria to propagate DNA plasmids or make recombinant proteins. We use cell lines as an in vitro system and mouse as an in vivo system to investigate the roles of RNA binding proteins in mammalian cells.
Special Equipment Desc: gloves, lab coats, hoods, biosafety cabinets, negative pressure rooms.

Project Title: Study the distribution of miRNAs in circulation systems
Project Description: MiRNAs and other non-coding RNAs inextracellular environment or in circulation system are carried by different components, such as protein complexes and vesicles. We will analyze the vesicles secreted from cells, and fractionate human serum and analyze the content of non-coding RNA and protein markers in different carriers. Better understanding of how those extracellular RNAs will be transported and secreted can be obtained.
Project Objectives: The objective is to identify new biomarkers for cancer diagnosis and new therapeutic strategies.
Special Equipment Desc: Biosafety Cabinet, Class II, A2. Autoclave for waste disposal. Sink installed in the room. PPE (lab coat, glove, goggle)

Project Title: Stem cell renewal and differentiation capacity
Project Description: In all of the above named projects, human embryonic stem cells, induced pluripotent stem cells and human mesenchymal stem cells will be expanded and differentiated into osteoblasts, the bone forming cells. The effect of certain compounds (i.e. alcohol, tobacco, nicotine and growth factors) on their differentiation capacity will be tested. In order to do so, differentiation protocols known form mouse cells, will be transferred and tissue markers tested at the gene and protein level. Apoptosis will be measured as well. The same type of experiments will also be performed with primate embryonic stem cells (the common marmoset monkey, Callithrix jacchus and rhesus, Macaca mulata). To control for adequate differentiation capacity, cells will be injected into immnuocompromised mice and teratoma formation assays be be performed. We aim to generate or use genetically modify human and mouse embryonic stem cells and induced pluripotent stem cells to carry fluorescent reporters, overexpress genes or knock-down (out) gene function. These reporter sequences are plasmid based or viral-based and will be transferred into the cells by nucleoporation, chemical transfection techniques or viral infection. Ultimately, these stem cell lines will help us discover the role of signalling pathways in pluripotency (self-renewal) and differentiation, but will also elucidate how stem cells respond to toxicants. We will be able to monitor the behaviour of the stem cells in response to such toxicants by fluorescent microscopy as well as videoimaging. We also study the driving role of microRNAs in cellular differentiation and will perform in utero manipulations of their expression levels. Toxicants will be injected into pregnant dams and embryos assessed for gene/protein expression and skeletal phenotype at specific stages of development.
Project Objectives: Our research will elucidate the molecular pathways, whereby pluripotent stem cells differentiate into osteoblasts. Here, the adult mesenchymal stem cells serve as control cells. In parts of our studies, we will then use this in vitro model to study toxic compounds. The negative effects of these compounds on embryonic development, which ultimately cause malformations, are well described. However, the molecular networks causing this maldevelopment are less well characterized. Using this in vitro model, we may discover molecular pathways, which may be targeted to prevent malformations otherwise caused by these compounds. Objective 1: Generation of reporter stem cell lines Objective 2: Cultivation and differentiation of the reporter stem cell lines Objective 3: Characterizing the response of the reporter stem cell lines to toxicants, chemicals, growth factors and shear
Special Equipment Desc: Lab coat, gloves
Medical Surveillance: Hepatitis B vaccination for all personnel handling the cells

Project Title: Insect neuroendocrinology
Funding: NIH, Pew Charitable Trusts, W.M.Keck Foundation
Project Description: The fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster has been extensively used as a model insect to study how insect development is controlled by hormones. Our project focuses on the genes that control hormone signaling. Findings in fruit flies will be applied and tested in other, more ecologically and economically relevant insect species such as the yellow fever mosquito Aedes aegypti.
Project Objectives: In order to check the gene functions, we use transgenic flies and mutant flies, and perform histochemistry and behavior analyses. In the course of these analyses, we sacrifice and dissect both larval and adult flies. We will also use transgenic mosquitoes and mutant mosquitoes to perform similar analyses. In some occasions, we will use human cell culture to express insect-derived genes to demonstrate its function in a different biological context (termed heterologous expression analysis).
Special Equipment Desc: Chemical hoods, safety glasses, UV shields, lab coats, gloves, screens on vents, sticky traps, double containment of insects, screen door, door brush

Project Title: Nanowire Endoscopy
Project Description: This project aims at developing a single nanowire-based multifunctional instrumental platform for high resolution and high precision sub-cellular sensing, imaging and payload delivery. Nanowire endoscope is a non-invasive probe that can communicate optical and electrical signal across cell membrane, as well as introduce thermal, chemical and biological stimuli with high spatiotemporal resolution. The small (picoliter) sensing/illumination volume ensures high resolution, high contrast, as well as low photodamage. Due to the small device footprint, the nanowire probe can directly access intracellular compartments without causing cell death or damaging cellular functions and structures. Application of this platform includes 3D intracellular fluorescent imaging and chemical mapping, local payload delivery and nanoelectrode for electrophysiology.
Project Objectives: Hela cells are used as a model system to test the capability of the nanowire endoscope.
Special Equipment Desc: Bio-safety cabinet, gloves, lab coats.

Project Title: Rop GTPase signaling in Arabidopsis
Funding: National Institute of Health, National Science Foundation, Department of Energy
Project Description: The goal of this project is to investigate the function of ROP GTPases and their associated proteins in signal transduction in Arabidopsis. An integrated genetic, molecular, cellular and biochemical approach will be used in this project. Arabidopsis genetic mutants created by T-DNA insertion, plasmid constructs transformed into E. coli and Agrobacterium tumefaciens, and transgenic Arabidopsis plants containing disarmed T-DNA will be used in this project.
Project Objectives: The work involving recombinant DNA and transgenic Arabidopsis plants will be used to investigate the function of ROP GTPases and their associated proteins and to understand how they are inovlved in plant signal transduction.

Project Title: Neuromodulation of decision making
Project Description: Neuromodulation has long thought to be important to regulate brain states and sensory processing, and disregulation of different neuromodulatory systems have been implicated in several psychiatric diseases. However, the knowledge of how these transmitters regulate animals behavior and perception is far from understood. Our studies aim to uncover the functions of neuromodulatory systems and their regulation of the brain, and thus provide a framework for understanding the behavioral manifestation of neurological diseases.
Project Objectives: We use replication deficient versions of adeno-associated virus. These vectors are used with inserts to express proteins for labeling and controlling neurons, such as fluorescent markers (GFP), and light-gated ion channels (channelrhodopsin-2). These inserts do not pose a known risk to human or animal health.
Special Equipment Desc: hood, negative pressure rooms, gloves, lab coats, goggles

Project Title: EphrinB signaling in dendritic spine development. MMP9 in Fragile X pathophysiology
Project Description: We are interested in understanding how the mammalian central nervous system initially develops and applying these principles to various neuropathologies associated with intellectual disabilities and the autism spectrum of disorders. Toward this end, We are currently working to more clearly define the mechanistic role of cell surface receptors, such as ephrins/Eph receptors and integrins, and secreted enzymes, matrix metalloproteinases, in the formation and maintenance of functional synaptic connections during development and in neurodegeneration. Recent evidence indicates that disruption of these interactions may be responsible, at least in part, for impaired memory and learning in clinically relevant conditions. As we work toward this goal, we will use transgenic mice, primary mouse hippocampal cell cultures, as well as established cell lines, such as HEK293 cells and CHO cells. We will also test expression and activity of these proteins in blood plasma samples, postmortem human brain tissues and cultures of iPSs from Fragile X Syndrome (FXS) subjects. Human FXS iPS cell lines used are HEL69.5, HEL70.3, HEL 100.1, and HEL100.2 that are previously characterized (Achuta et al., 2017. 2018) and new cell lines HEL42.5, HEL69.6, and HEL70.6 are included for replicate studies. Control cell lines are HEL46.111, HEL23.31,3, and HEL11.41,4. The iPS cell lines were reprogammed from male somatic cells in Stem Cell Center of Biomedicum Helsinki and written informed consent was used when collecting cell samples. All human cells will be de-identified for this study. We use proteomics and genomics analysis to characterize the changes in FXS cells.
Project Objectives: Human cell cultures provide an excellent system to study the changes in controlled conditions. The recombinant DNA technology will allow to probe the precise functions of gene products and to more precisely investigate their roles in normal and abnormal human cells. Analysis of the MMP levels in blood plasma, especially gelatinases MMP-2 and MMP-9, is already suggested as a diagnostic tool for patients with breast cancer and acute coronary syndromes (Ryan et al., 2001. Kai et al., 1998. Ranuncolo et al., 2003), so if an increase in the levels of MMP-9 or other MMPs is detected in FXS subjects this could potentially become a valuable diagnostic tool for FXS and possibly other neurodevelopmental disorders. Gene, lipid and protein analysis will allow to probe the precise functions of gene products in human astrocytes and neurons derived from iPSc and to more precisely investigate their roles in normal and abnormal synapse development in the human cell cultures provide an excellent system to study the process of synapse formation in controlled conditions.
Special Equipment Desc: The procedures involving human cell lines and blood/tissue samples will be performed in a biosafety cabinet. Lab personnel will wear a personal protective equipment, including lab coat, gloves, mask and safety glasses, when handling a potentially infectious materials. Disposal procedures: Liquids: bleach will be added to a final concentration of 10% bleach solution (Clorox) for 30 minutes, disposed in sink with running water. Aspirator flasks: bleach will be added to aspirator flasks to a final concentration 10%. Flasks will be emptied at weekly. Surface: 10% household bleach solution made up fresh daily (Clorox) allowing 5-minutes contact time.
Medical Surveillance: 1. Wash the exposed area with soap and water 2. Report the incident to supervisor and EH&S for additional support and medical attention

Project Title: Regulation of plant defense genes
Project Description: To defend themselves against microbial attack, plants have evolved a highly effective immune system. Recognition of pathogenic microorganisms induces coordinated up-regulation of a multitude of defense genes. We are interested in regulatory mechanisms controlling such extensive transcriptional re-programming in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana (Arabidopsis). Using micro-arrays we identified several groups of genes responding in a highly coordinated manner to pathogen recognition. The pathogen we use for such experiments is the Oomycete Pernospoa parasitica. Applying a variety of different methods we want to identify proteins (transcription factors) responsible for coordinated defense gene expression in Arabidopsis. The planned approaches will involve use of transgenic Arabidopsis lines plants transformed with reporter genes as well as with T-DNA insertions in genes of interest. These transgenic lines will be infected with spores of Hyalopersonospora arabidopsidis.
Project Objectives: 1.)transgenic Arabidopsis lines transformed with reporter genes will be used to identify and test putative cis-elements that are required for defense gene expression. We will test sequence motifs that are conserved in promoters of co-regulated genes (such conserved motifs may constitute cis-elements common to these genes). We will also fuse promoters of representative members of such gene groups to reporter genes and identify important cis-elements by deletion analysis of these reporter genes in transgenic Arabidopsis plants. 2.)Transgenic Arabidopsis lines with T-DNA insertions will be used to test genes that are potentially involved in defense gene regulation. T-DNAs are relative large DNA stretches from Argobacgterium tumefaciens. They can randomly insert into plant genomic DNA and disrupt genes. There are several collections of Arabidopsis mutants with T-DNA insertions in defined genes from the SALK institute or Syngenta. Lines with insertions in putative regulatory genes that showed interesting expression patterns in our micro array experiments will be tested for their roles in the plant immune system using such T-DNA mutants. 3.)Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis will be used as a stimulus for above mentioned reporter gene assyas as well as for testing T-DNA insertion mutants for a reduction in their defense capability. 4.) chemicals that induce expression of H. arabidopsidis responsive reporter genes will be tested to deterime if they induce plant immune responses.
Special Equipment Desc: I need a type 2A biosafety cabinet for work with the plant pathogen Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis. Work with Pseudomonas syringe and Botrytis cinerea will also be exclusively performed in this biosafety cabinet.

Project Title: recombinant DNA and protein expression
Project Description: To express recombinant proteins in bacteria and insect cells for protein crystallization and structure studies.
Project Objectives: To express recombinant proteins in bacteria and insect cells for protein crystallization and structure studies.

Project Title: Molecular Biology of Insect Pathogenic Bacteria and Viruses
Funding: National Institutes of Health, National Institute of Health, United States Department of Agriculture, possible corporate sponsors
Project Description: This application covers two projects, genetic engineering of insect pathogenic bacteria to improve bacterial larvicides, and recombinant DNA technology used as part of studies aimed at understanding the molecular biology of insect pathogenic viruses. Special containment equipment is used for the bacteria (Bacillus thuringiensis and Lysinibacillus sphaericus) and viruses (baculoviruses and ascoviruses), however, it has been demonstrated these only infect insects - they pose no risks for humans or other vertebrate animals. Also, we only work with insect cell lines - no plant or vertebrate cell lines. We have worked with the above bacteria and viruses for over 30 years under the conditions described.
Project Objectives: In the first project, our objective is to improve the efficacy of commercial bacterial larvicides as well as improve our understanding of gene expression in these bacteria. These "biohazardous" materials are only hazardous to insects - they are not harmful to humans - you eat them everyday. The objectives of the studies of insect pathogenic viruses is to clarify their basic and molecular biology.
Special Equipment Desc: We use sterile hoods, not because our cells, DNA, bacteria or viruses are hazardous, but to avoid contamination.
Medical Surveillance: None. As noted elsewhere in this BUA, we have worked with these insect-pathogenic bacteria and viruses for more than 35 years without any incidents of infection. These agents are highly specific for their insect hosts.

Project Title: Astrocyte optogenetics, NIH
Project Description: The purpose of the project is to determine the effects of astrocyte swelling on neuronal excitability. It is important to develop a means to manipulate astrocyte volume selectively in our brain tissue slices. Current techniques may not be selective for astrocytes, clouding interpretation of data. Optogenetics may provide a means to manipulate astrocyte volume selectively and with precise temporal and spatial control.
Project Objectives: We will use recombinant DNA and replication deficient adenoassociated viruses (AAVs) to drive expression of ion channels only in astrocytes. Stimulation of ion influx into astrocytes may be associated with an astrocyte-specific water influx, thereby causing astrocyte swelling selectively. Injection of AAV constructs will take place in the Riccomagno Laboratory, room 1215 Biological Sciences. The Riccomagno lab is approved to perform these injections as per their AUP. After injection of the pups at P5, the animals will be returned to care from their mother and housed in the Boyce Hall vivarium until used for experiments beginning 2 weeks after injection. Pups will be moved individually to the Fiacco Lab (room 1210) to perform imaging and optogenetics experiments in hippocampal slices as detailed in the Fiacco Lab AUP and SOP.
Special Equipment Desc: biosafety cabinets gloves lab coat Goggles splash shield respirator

Project Title: Plant Microbe Interaction Research
Project Description: My research focuses on understanding the molecular basis of plant-microbe interactions. Project Title: Molecular Interactions During Neural Crest Formation(NIH,NIDCR)
Project Description: Neural crest cells (NC) contribute to a wide range of derivatives including neurons and glia of the peripheral nervous system and melanocytes of the skin, and a wealth of craniofacial derivatives, including tooth forming cells, bone and cartilage. Aberrant NC development is responsible for many human pathologies. The purpose of this project is to reveal basic principles of NC development in avian and rabbit embryos and in a model of human NC development. We will pinpoint the role(s) of known and novel players in the origin and differentiation of neural crest cells. Additionally we will model specific mutations of genes involved in cleft lip and/or palate, and we will assess their effects in survival, proliferation, expression and differentiation of neural crest derivatives.
Project Objectives: We have developed a unique model of human Neural crest cells based in hESCs. We will take advantage of this model to identify novel components of the gene regulatory network controlling the origin and differentiation potential of neural crest cells. We will determine the role of known and novel putative-components of this gene regulatory network. We will assess the signaling requirements for human neural crest formation and differentiation. In particular we will tackle BMP, FGF, Wnt, Insulin, and Retinoid signaling pathways amongst others. We aim to determine their time of operation, their transcriptional effectors and their targets. An additional goal of this project is to establish the ontogeny of human neural crest cells. To this end specific lineages will be induced or inhibited while monitoring specific effects on neural crest formation/differentiation. We will also address the heterogeneity and pluripotency of neural crest cells based on transcription factor expression profiles. Finally, we will develop a platform of assays to address the currently unknown effects of known mutations involved in craniofacial malformations like cleft lip and/or cleft palate. These assays will allow us to determine the specific effects altered by such mutations (proliferation, survival, differentiation, integration, etc).

Project Title: Study of Endothelial Cells in Health and Disease
Project Description: Endothelial cells (ECs) play a crucial role in human health and disease. This is because they are responsible for both the formation and function of blood vessels that deliver nutrients and oxygen to various tissues and organs. ECs also regulate the infiltration of immune cells in tissues and subsequent tissue debridement. Thus, it is not surprising that EC dysfunction, which leads to excessive vessel formation and/or immune cell infiltration, contributes to various debilitating conditions including diabetic retinopathy, age-related macular degeneration, and atherosclerosis. Yet, precisely how ECs function in health and become dysfunctional in disease remains poorly understood. Recent studies by our group and others have shown that EC behavior is regulated not only by genetic and chemical factors but also by cell-generated mechanical forces, which manifests as cell stiffness. The working hypothesis of our labs research is that abnormal EC stiffness leads to abnormal blood vessel formation and function that is characteristic of the aforementioned pathological conditions. To test this hypothesis, we are performing studies where the stiffness of endothelial cells and their underlying sub-endothelial matrix are altered and their effects on endothelial cell behavior (activation and differentiation) assessed. Some of the important EC-specific functional responses that we are investigating are the expression of pro-inflammatory protein ICAM-1, endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS), matrix crosslinking enzyme lysyl oxidase (LOX), all of which actively regulate blood vessel formation and function. Findings from these studies will provide new therapeutic targets for improving blood vessel formation and function in the aforementioned diseases.
Project Objectives: To perform studies aimed at determining the role of endothelial stiffness in blood vessel formation and function in both health and disease, our laboratory uses endothelial cell cultures derived from both humans and animals. We simultaneously use human and animal blood to formulate red blood cell-derived vascular-targeting nanoparticles for site-specific treatment of vascular defects.

Project Title: Microbiome and Pathogenesis of Vibrio cholerae
Project Description: This project seeks to define the mechanism underlying interactions between the commensal gut microbiome and human pathogens, especially the diarrheal pathogen Vibrio cholerae. These studies will involve the culturing of commensal microbiota strains in aerobic and anaerobic conditions, and assembly into defined communities for introduction into germ-free mice. The ability of V. cholerae strains to invade these communities, both of V. cholerae wild-type and mutants in quorum signaling and pathogenesis regulator pathways, will then be assessed. V. cholerae colonization will be measured by dilution plating and CFU counting from fecal samples collected from infected animals. The ability of commensal isolates to produce or process molecules important for regulating V. cholerae pathogenesis will also be measured through biological reporter assays in which supernatants from commensal isolates are added to Vibrio reporter strains, or experiments in which V. cholerae is co-cultured with commensal bacteria. Levels of signaling molecules of interested in infected animals will be assayed by reporter measurements of tissue homogenates, mass spectroscopy, ELISA, or in vitro colorimetric or enzymatic assays. Interactions of microbiomes and Vibrio in vivo will be assayed by colonizing conventional, antibiotic treated conventional, and germ-free mice with different communities of commensal microbes, infecting these animals with V. cholerae, and measuring pathogen colonization, gene expression, and host physiological, immunological, and transcriptional changes as readouts.
Project Objectives: The work with biohazardous materials involves direct measurement of the colonization potential of the human pathogen Vibrio cholerae in the presence of specific members of the human gut microbiome and host responses to microbiome, diet, and infection. The ultimate goal is to identify specific genes in V. cholerae that contribute to pathogenesis but are modified in function by products of the gut microbiota. Such studies will necessarily involve V. cholerae with mutations in genes that contribute to virulence, such as those related to metabolism, cell signaling, motility, gene regulation, and virulence factor production. The role of specific V. cholerae genes and human microbiomes in commensal-pathogen interactions will be tested by assembling communities of bacteria in germ-free mice and infecting animals with wild-type or mutant V. cholerae. Tissues and fecal material will be taken from infected animals, and the levels of V. cholerae and microbial gene expression assessed in the lab. These studies include establishing defined and undefined human gut microbiomes from human donors in mice. This involves the isolation in pure culture of commensal species from human fecal samples, to obtain "wild" isolates of gut microbes to test in germfree animals. Alternatively, human microbiomes will be established in mice through inoculation with suspensions of human fecal samples from healthy (uninfected) donors.

Project Title: Genetic Studies of Memory
Funding: NIH, The Brain and Behavior Research Fundation
Project Description: Current evidence strongly suggests that the interplay between the prefrontal cortex and hippocampus is critical for learning and memory. The central goal of this project is to define the role of the mPFC neural network in fear memory specificity and determine the functional relations between the mPFC and hippocampus in the generation and retrieval of distinct memories that are resistant to confusion. Our main hypothesis is that the mPFC is critical for the integration of information necessary for learning subtle differences between temporally separated relevant and non-relevant stimuli. My laboratory at UCR has developed a new genetic methodology to target neurons in the prefrontal cortex and manipulate selectively their role in a type of synaptic plasticity underlying long-term memory consolidation without disconnecting them from the circuit and diminishing their abilities to support working memory, attention, information acquisition, and short-term memory. The procedure involves virus-mediated gene delivery facilitated with stereotactic survival surgery to different brain regions such as prefrontal cortex, hippocampus and thalamus. Mutant mice are tested using behavioral, electrophysiological and histological techniques to define the role of prefrontal neuronal circuits in memory. The proposed research is relevant to impaired cognitive function caused by maladaptations in neural circuitry. These type of neural maladaptations of neural circuits are likely to be associated with neural processes underlying post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) or developmental disorders such as Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome (RTS) and schizophrenia.
Project Objectives: we use viruses to deliver genes to specific cell types in mouse brains regions in order to manipulate neural activity and cognitive functioning.

Project Title: Engineering aluminum tolerance in crop plants
Project Description: Aluminum (Al) toxicity in acid soils is a global problem that severely limits crop growth and productivity. Significant work has focused on developing a basic knowledge of Al toxicity and resistance and at the same time devising schemes to modify crop plants to allow them to thrive in such an inhospitable environment, yet our understanding of the biochemical and molecular mechanisms underlying Al toxicity and resistance remain limited. Our work utilizes a previously described Al-sensitive Arabidopsis mutant, als3-1, to identify mutations that can be used to confer increases in Al resistance/tolerance. Since als3-1 has been found to have extreme negative responses to levels of Al that have no effect on growth of wild type roots, this mutant is a powerful tool to allow us to easily identify suppressor mutations that give increased Al resistance and to successfully use a map-based cloning approach to isolate the mutations of interest. We have undertaken an approach whereby als3-1 has been treated with the mutagenic agent EMS and M1 seedlings have been screened to identify mutants capable of sustaining wt or greater root growth in the presence of inhibitory concentrations of Al. From this approach, 15 confirmed strong alt (Al tolerant) mutants have been identified, with roots of these at the very least fully reversing the severe affects of Al toxicity on growth of als3-1. Of the 15 strong alt mutants, at least 9 of these have been found to represent dominant mutations, suggesting that these represent gain-of-function mutations that may positively affect a documented mechanism of Al resistance such as organic acid release, rhizosphere alkalinization, or Al sequestration. Our work focuses initially on cloning five of the alt mutations. Following isolation of the mutations, we will subsequently work to characterize the ALT genes with regard to their roles in Al resistance/tolerance using relevant biochemical, molecular, and physiological tools. Additionally, our work has focused on identifying mutations that can increase Al resistance associated with malate release into the rhizosphere. This has resulted in identification of multiple mutations that improve the function and activity of a key carbon fixation step in plants, Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxylase. This enzyme is important to several processes including C4 photosynthesis and amino acid biosynthesis. As part of our research to translate our findings into crop plants, our alr mutations will be introduced into PPC's found in maize in order to determine whether these will increase carbon fixation in the transgenic plants.
Project Objectives: Some of the objectives of this work focus on cloning and characterization of the mutations of interest. Work will involved working with mutant plants, transgenic plants, engineered E. coli and engineered Agrobacterium tumafaciens. All genetically engineered organisms, both plant and microbial, will be disposed of properly by collecting and subsequently autoclaving them. With regard to the maize work, transgenic plants will be generated in order to determine whether the introduced alr mutations can enhance PPC activity. This will be measured through analysis of carbon fixation rates as well as rates of photosynthetic output, metabolic profiles and growth in aluminum toxic environments.
