Project Title: Understanding the Life Cycle Progression of Apicomplexan Parasites.
Project Description: Our Research Our research focuses on developing biological and technological tools to dissect the molecular events driving apicomplexan parasites with a particular interest in malaria parasite life cycle progression. Using functional genomics approaches, we expect to elucidate critical regulatory networks driving the parasite life cycles and identify novel therapeutic strategies. There are three main research projects ongoing in the laboratory 1. Revealing mechanisms controlling gene expression in the Apicomplexan parasites Mechanisms controlling gene expression in Apicomplexan parasites are still poorly understood. Rising evidences indicate that control of gene expression in the malaria parasites occurs at multiple levels, one of those being chromatin remodeling. It is increasingly apparent that histone turnover and histone post-translational modifications are important in chromatin structure and transcriptional regulation. Determination of chromatins structural changes will therefore be critical for the understanding of transcriptional regulation in Apicomplexan parasites including human malaria parasites . Using genome wide complementary approaches. we are investigating the parasite dynamic chromatin structure and the molecular components that regulate their features. 2. Drug discovery and natural products In addition to fundamental scientific approaches, we are developing drug-screening assays and high content live cell confocal imaging technologies to identify small molecule inhibitors and their morphological effects on the Apicomplexan parasites. Ongoing collaborations with several institutes are providing us with a comprehensive array of natural products. So far we have already uncovered several compounds that can inhibit malaria growth in the low nano molar ranges. Experiments to identify drug targets and drug mechanism of actions are still ongoing. 3  Detection of small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) in mosquitoes to improve surveillance of emerging mosquito borne diseases in California. The most recent project developed in my lab is designed to develop a new genome wide technology to detect infectious diseases in mosquitoes. We want to detect in a genome-wide manner old and new infectious agents to prevent widespread of human disease transmitted by mosquitoes. This innovative work is done in collaboration with Mosquito and Vector Control Districts and is funded through the CDC to the Pacific Southwest Regional Center of Excellence for Vector-Borne Disease Research at the University of California (UCR and UCD). Note that that my lab only received total RNA extracted from mosquitoes in approved facilities. We do not grow or collect mosquitoes in my lab.
Project Objectives: 1- Development of new biological tools to dissect the molecular events driving Apicomplexan parasites 2- Discovery of new targets and therapeutic approaches for the treatment of Apicomplexan parasites. 3- Improve surveillance of emerging mosquito borne diseases in California.

Project Title: Evolutionary Development of Plants
Project Description: We are interested in how changes in gene function during the course of plant evolution have produced changes in plant form and function. Our focus is on flower and fruit diversity and the evolutionary changes in the genes that determine flower and fruit morphology. Our work centers on two closely related plant development genes, AP1 and FUL. In Arabidopsis, both are required for proper flower development, but AP1 is also required for sepals and petals to form, whereas FUL is important in the development of the dry capsule-like fruit of Arabidopsis. AP1 and FUL arose from a gene duplication, and although their sequences are similar, there are short amino acid motifs that distinguish them, and their expression patterns are different. We are interested in whether the observed differences in function are the result of the different amino acid motifs or the differences in expression. We will be growing transgenic Arabidopsis (produced in another lab) which contain constructs with mutations that disrupt the amino acid motifs or that alter gene expression to answer this question. We may also make crosses with other Arabidopsis mutants. We are also investigating the role of FUL genes in fruit development in the tomato family. Many members of this family produce seeds in a dry pod-like fruit whereas others produce a fleshy edible fruit. We are interested in the role of changes in FUL function in the development of dry and fleshy fruit and will be comparing gene function in tomato and desert tobacco, which has a capsule-type fruit. These species both have four copies of the FUL gene. to investigate the origin of all these copies we are amplifying FUL genes from a variety of species in the family, from the earliest diverging members to the most advanced, and are cloning them into E. coli for sequencing. We will be looking at the number of genes as well as their sequences, to determine if any of the four groups of FUL genes has evolved more slowly or quickly. We will also be using agrobacterium-mediated CRISPR technology to knock out each gene individually (four in tomato, four in desert tobacco) using a tissue-culture process. The four genes fall into two pairs, euFULI and euFULII, and we will either use CRISPR or make crosses to make double mutants, and finally quadruple knock-outs. The goal is to determine if there are functional differences between euFULI and euFULII genes, and to determine if there are redundant functions that can only be uncovered if all are knocked out. Our goal is to understand how changes in FUL function may have contributed to the evolution of fleshy fruit from dry fruit in this family.
Project Objectives: None of the materials are particularly hazardous, but the goals are: (1) transgenic E. coli - our procedure to amplify FUL genes from tomato-family members will produce product containing multiple different gene sequences. To separate these and identify the ones relevant for us, we will clone the amplification product into E. coli and sequence plasmids that may contain a FUL gene. We will use these sequences in analyses to identify when duplications occurred, and to analyze sequence evolution. This may help us determine that specific groups of FUL genes may have undergone functional changes, or that changes in gene sequence are correlated with the origin of fleshy fruit from dry fruit. (2) transgenic Agrobacterium - will be generated to introduce CRISPR-Cas9 constructs into tomato and desert tobacco to knock out the function of FUL genes to characterize their function in fruit and flower development. (3) transgenic tomato and desert tobacco - we will be using CRISPR to knock out each of the four FUL genes separately, and will also look at double and quadruple mutants. (4) transgenic Datura - we are working on developing a transformation system for this species, which independently evolved a dry fruit, to expand the scope of our study. We will characterize the function of FUL genes in dry and fleshy fruit development, which will help elucidate how fleshy fruit, which are economically and ecologically important, arose from dry fruit during the course of the evolution of the tomato family. Fleshy fruit have evolved from dry fruit many times in many plant families, and this work will contribute to a greater understanding of the mechanisms by which this occurred. Potentially, the project will identify gene functions relevant for plant breeding or engineering.
Special Equipment Desc: lab coat, gloves, eye protection

Project Title: Regulation of p53 by TAF1
Project Description: Alteration or loss of the p53 tumor suppressor gene is the most frequent lesion detected in cancer. Our research projects focus on the molecular mechanisms by which cells regulate p53 transcriptional activity in response to DNA damage. The p53 tumor suppressor protein plays an important role in the cellular response to stress such as DNA damage. The biochemical activity of p53 that is required for this relies on its ability to bind to specific DNA sequences and to function as a transcription factor . Recently, we identified Thr-55 as a novel phosphorylation site on human p53 and showed that TAFI, the largest subunit of transcription factor TFIID complex, is responsible for the phosphorylation. TAFI is identical to CCG1, a cell cycle regulatory protein important for progression through the G1 phase and apoptosis. We observed that the phosphorylation of Thr55 by TAFI results in p53 degradation and leads to a decrease in G1 arrest. Importantly, the Thr55 phosphorylation was much reduced following DNA damage, which suggests that this phosphorylation contributes to the stabilization of p53 in response to DNA damage. Thus, phosphorylation by TAFI and the resultant destabilization of p53 provide a novel mechanism for regulation of the cell cycle in response to DNA damage. We propose to characterize the molecular mechanisms by which TAFI regulates the stability of p53 in response to DNA damage. First, we will identify the domains of TAFI required for p53 interaction and phosphorylation and we will examine whether TAFI double bromodomains (DBrD) are required for the interaction. Second, we will further characterize the role of Thr55 phosphorylation in TAFI-mediated cell G1 progression and apoptosis. Third, as p53 is a DNA-bound transcription activator and TAFI is a component of general transcription machinery, we will examine whether phosphorylation of p53 by TAFI occurs during the act of transcription. Fourth, we will define the underlying molecular mechanisms of Thr55
Project Objectives: For this amendment, we include lentivirus in our research. Specifically, we plan to use packaged lentivirus to knock down or overexposes p53, TAF1 and lncRNA and study their function in cancer. We will use 3rd generation lentiviral expression system.

Project Title: Cell Interactions with Biomaterials - Huinan Liu Lab BUA

Project Description: The overall goal is to design and fabricate biomaterial scaffolds for bone, cartilage and neural regeneration. Candidate materials include biodegradable metals (e.g. magnesium alloys, iron alloys), graphene, collagen hydrogels and composites. Additional surface coatings can improve cellular adhesion and control biomaterial degradation. Cellular biocompatibility, cytotoxicity, and stem cell differentiation will be determined using both stem cells and differentiated cell types. This research is essential to verify the biocompatibility of a scaffold prior to conducting any in vivo experiments. We will be obtaining fresh human blood to test the hemocytocompatability of new materials. A circulation flow device will be developed for this test.  We will be testing E. coli (ATTC 25922) and other non pathogenic bacteria (Enterobacter aerogenes ATCC 35028,Bacillus subtilis ATCC 7060, Serratia marcescens ATCC 8195, S. Epidermidis), Pseduomonas aeruginosa (ATCC 29260), Staphylococcus aureus(ATCC 25923), Methicillin Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA, ATCC 33591) with biomaterials as part of a study on resorbable implant materials for urilogical applications. Human cell lines will be utilized to closely examine how specific cells may react with the scaffolds. We do not use recombinant methods or transgenic organisms. Our cells are established cell lines from ATCC and established stem cells at UCR Stem cell core. The objective is to test bacterial and microbial response to novel antimicrobial biomaterials for biomedical applicaitons. Non pathogenic and pathogenic bacteria and yeast will be used.

Project Title: Host-Pathogen interactions
Project Description: Human pathogenic bacteria (Salmonella typhimurium, Yersinia enterocolitica, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumonia, Vibrio cholerae) and the inocuous soil bacteria Bacillus subtilis engineered to express fluorescent proteins will be grown to test their uptake in mouse tissues in terminal procedures. A mouse pathogen Citrobacter rodentium (including a variant expressing EGFP) that does not infect humans will also be used in infection studies. For in vivo studies on biofilm formation and host response, a non-MRSA strain of S. aureus (UAMS-1) will be use to infect subcutaneous silicone catheter implants in ear pinnae. Serial multi photon imaging will be performed over the course of 0 to 9 days. In some terminal procedures with mice (lab only, non-vivarium) we may also use the MRSA strain USA300 expressing EGFP.
Project Objectives: In studies with fluorescent bacteria and B. subtilis we will be studying the mechanisms of uptake by mucosal immune tissue in comparison with synthetic vaccine microparticles, and mechanisms of microbial activation of mucosal immune responses. S. aureus is commonly found colonizing skin and upper airways, but can be pathogenic when infecting tissues and implanted medical devices (catheter, artificial joints). We plan to use intravital imaging to follow host response to implanted catheters infected with S. aureus.

Project Title: Molecular mechanisms underlying plant-pathogen interactions
Funding: NSF USDA-NIFA USDA-APHIS UCR AES-CE RSAP UCR Office of Research Citrus Research Board Citrus Research and Development Foundation
Project Description: My research program is focused on understanding the mechanisms by which bacterial and oomycete pathogens facilitate infection of their plant hosts. The major focus in my lab is to use effector proteins produced by the plant pathogens Candidatus Liberibacter (a bacterium) and Phytophthora species (a group of oomycete, filamentous eukaryotic pathogens) to study genes in pathogens that are involved in promoting infection of plant hosts, such as citrus, soybean, tobacco and Arabidopsis. An integrative approach using a combination of genomic, genetic, molecular, biochemical and cell biology methods is employed to address fundamental questions including what are the key virulence factors that contribute to plant disease. what are their roles during infection. and how have they evolved during the arms race with plant defense mechanisms. Our work on the citrus bacterial pathogens Candidatus Liberibacter also aims to develop diagnostic methods for citrus Huanglongbing (HLB). This project will significantly advance our understanding of the molecular basis of plant-microbe interactions and contribute to the development of novel, effective and sustainable disease management strategies.
Project Objectives: To study the functions of pathogen effectors, we will generate transgenic bacteria, Phytophthora, and plants (mainly Arabidopsis) that either over-expressing specific effector genes or with reduced expression of these effectors. Specific experimental procedures include standard molecular cloning techniques, biochemical analysis and plant infection assays. The molecular cloning procedures include: genomic DNA isolation. PCR. gene cloning in plasmid vectors replicating in E. coli, yeast and plants (Arabidopsis, citrus, soybean and tobacco). constructing mutant strains by over-expressing genes of interest or knocking out genes of interest in Phytophthora species. Plant (Arabidopsis, soybean and tobacco) infection assays involve inoculating plant leaves or roots with bacterial cell or Phytophthora zoospore suspensions, followed by the evaluation of disease progression at 3-6 days after inoculation. These are all standard protocols that are well-established and have been used in numerous labs worldwide. We are planning to maintain citrus seedlings infected with Candidatus Liberibacter in a BSL3 facility that will become available to research in Fall 2018.

The Room has a clear sign on the door with access by authorized personnel only. The door remains closed all the time and locked after regular work hours.

Project Title: Nematode Development and Differentiation
Funding: National Science Foundation (NSF), National Institutes of Health (NIH)
Project Description: Our laboratory studies genetic mechanisms of development in the nematode, C. elegans, as well as other non-pathogenic nematodes that are related to C. elegans. We also examine the function of cells in differentiated tissues of C. elegans and related nematodes. Recently we are exploring expression of genes in the pathogenic nematode Steinernema that infects some insect larvae. We will propagate the nematodes on agar plates supplemented with Xenorhabdus bacteria.
Project Objectives: Recombinant DNA technology will be used for the following purposes: 1. To generate novel fusion genes that will be introduced into nematodes. 2. To generate constructs that will be introduced into E. coli for the purpose of expressing and purifying recombinant proteins. 3. To propagate segments of nematode genes in E. coli for the purposes of sequencing or generation of RNA. 4. To propagate segments of genes that will be used as intermediates to generate other recombinant DNA. 5. To use and generate reagents that can cause directed modification of DNA in nematode chromosomes. 6. To test C. elegans developmental mutant strains for their ability to grow on Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteria, a commonly used species to study C. elegans immunity.

Project Title: Understanding Plant immunity to oomycete pathogens
Funding: UCR Initial Complement, California Avocado Commission (CAC), California Department of food and agriculture (CDFA)
Project Description: The primary research goal of my laboratory is to elucidate the molecular and genetic basis of plant immunity against oomycete pathogens with an emphasis on Phytophthora cinnamomi (Pc) in model plants (Arabidopsis) and avocado. The identification of candidate genes associated with resistance against this oomycete pathogen will be a key aspect for the generation of molecular markers for Marker Assisted Selection (MAS) to develop new resistant avocado rootstock varieties. One of the main goals of my multidisciplinary research program is to apply and incorporate the basic knowledge and information we gain from basic research in my lab into the UCR Avocado Rootstock Breeding program. The UCR avocado breeding program aims to develop a set of genomic tool for avocado breeding worldwide. My research aims to 1) understand how the CRT1/MORC1 gene family, a GHKL ATPase, modulates plant immunity against oomycete pathogens in plants. We found that this gene family functions in multiple layers of plant immunity in Arabidopsis, barley, and Solanaceous crops. We will use molecular, genetic, and genomic approaches to understand how this gene family regulates plant immunity, 2) Elucidate the molecular and genetic basis of plant immunity against Phytophthora cinnamomi (Pc), the causal agent of Phytophthora root rot, the most destructive disease of avocado worldwide. We study plant-Pc. interactions in model plants (Arabidopsis) and crops (Avocado) using molecular, genetic, and genomic approaches including transcriptome analysis, 3) Identification and characterization of proteins from P. cinnamomi that are critical for pathogen fitness and virulence. In addition, we want to understand the molecular basis of the broad host specialization of Pc isolates from California using comparative genomics. Recently, a new introduction of potentially more aggressive Pc isolates has been found in Southern CA avocado growing areas. We are currently working on the phenotypic and molecular characterization of these Pc isolates.
Project Objectives: 1- Identification and characterization of genes and proteins from P. cinnamomi that are critical for pathogen fitness, virulence, and host range. 2- Identification and characterization of genes and proteins from the plants host of this oomycete pathogen that are involve during different layers of the plant immune responses.

Project Title: Gene regulation by oncoproteins, chromatin coregulators and lncRNAs
Project Description: Study of transcription factors, chormatin-modifying cofactors, long non-coding RNAs, and cognate mechanisms involved in regulation of chromatin and transcription of specific genes during cell proliferation and differentiation and in cancer cells using in vitro systems, cultured mammalian cells, and mouse models. Culture and transfection of mammalian cells with promoter/reporter vectors, cDNA and RNAi expression vectors, and gene editing vectors (such as CRISPR/Cas system) to study gene regulation in vivo. Overexpression of Myc and associated cofactors in human cells with recombinant replication-deficient viruses.

Project Title: Effects of Inflammation and Infection on Intestinal Epithelial Biology

Project Title: McFrederick Bee Symbiosis Lab
Project Description: The McFrederick lab studies interactions between microbes that associate with both wild and domesticated bees. For example, we routinely isolate bacteria and fungi from bee nests that have been collected in the field. We use these isolated Bacteria and Fungi to conduct Bioassays with the bee hosts to determine whether interactions between fungi, bacteria and the host influence host development, growth and reproduction. For example, we isolate bacteria in the genera Lactobacillus, Fructobacillus, and Saccharibacter and saprophytic fungi in the genera Cladosporium, Alternaria, Aspergillus and Pleospora. We have purchased/been given bees from across state lines, e.g. Idaho and Utah. However, the movement of these bees (Megachile rotundata) is not regulated by the USDA or CDFA, and therefore no permits are required for this transport. We also work with bee-specific viruses, such as Deformed Wing Virus and Israeli Acute Paralysis Virus. These are common viruses in California bee populations, so we will not impact wild or agriculturally important bee populations by isolating these viruses. Finally, we work with a fungal pathogen (Ascosphaera aggregata) that is specific to the alfalfa leafcutter bee Megachile rotundata. We monitor the growth of this pathogen in the presence of other fungi and bacteria, in order to determine whether specific bacteria or fungi can inhibit the pathogen's growth.
Project Objectives: The specific objectives of our work are to understand how bee-associated microbes are spread, how these microbes affect bee health, and ultimately, whether we can increase the availability of beneficial microbes such as Lactobacilli to managed and wild bee populations. We therefore view the goal of our worjk as conservation of pollinating insect populations through the study of symbiosis.

Project Title: The Role of Mechanical Stimuli on Multi-directional Stem Cell Differentiation
Project Description: Skeletal diseases such as osteoarthritis and osteoporosis afflict more than 40% of all adults and more than 70% of aging populations. This project aims to provide the information regarding the use of stem cell for cartilage and bone regeneration. The knowledge obtained from this project will provide invaluable information for the stem cell based treatment for skeletal diseases.
Project Objectives: This project aims to examine the effects of mechanical stimuli on the differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cells to multiple terminal phenotypes, specifically chondrocytes and osteoblasts in vitro. Commercially available human mesenchymal stem cells will be cultured in three-dimensional scaffolds, and the cell/scaffold constructs will be subjected to dynamic compressive strains, followed by examinations for their differentiation.

Project Title: "Discovery of a novel signal that enhances germination and seedling growth" - NSF "Karrikin and strigolactone signaling mechanisms in Arabidopsis" - NSF
Project Description: Karrikins are a class of compounds found in smoke that activate germination of many plant species after fire. Strigolactones comprise a family of plant hormones that regulate growth processes such as shoot branching, root architecture, and cambial growth. Strigolactones also trigger germination of the highly destructive parasitic weeds broomrapes and witchweeds, and promote symbiotic associations with arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi. Our goal is to understand the molecular mechanisms by which karrikins and strigolactones control plant growth, which may help us develop new innovations in crop development and weed control. We are not only interested in how these signaling mechanisms work, but how they have evolved in different plants.
Project Objectives: Our goals are to characterize the function of genes and proteins involved in karrikin and strigolactone signaling. These experiments involve the transfer and modification of genes from plants into E. coli, yeast, Agrobacterium tumefaciens, and plants.

Project Title: Construction of agro-infectious clones of CYSDV
Project Description: In the United States, Cucurbit yellow stunting disorder virus (CYSDV) is rampant in melon-production fields in the Southwest,including California and Arizona. Based on comparative coat protein nucleotide sequence analyses, CYSDV isolates can be grouped into two diverged subpopulations: an Eastern subpopulation, and a Western subpopulation. The latter, to which the Californian CYSDV isolates belong, is the most prevalent in the United States. One of the goals of this project is to help the industry identify the diversity of these isolates, and this will be determined using high-throughput RNA-seq Illumina sequencing technology. The project also aims to develop the cloned infectious cDNAs of one or more of these CYSDV isolates to be used in conjunction with agroinoculation for the mass screening of cucurbit hosts for resistance against the virus.
Project Objectives: The specific objectives of the work are: 1.Sample CYSDV isolates from Cucurbit crops in California, preferably cucumber. 2.Generation of full-length CYSDV cDNA clones and the re-sequencing of these clones. 3.Select cDNA clones to be used for engineering the full-length cDNAs (corresponding to the viral genomic RNAs) in binary vectors. 4.Perform experiments to determine if the full-length cDNA clones are capable of initiating infection in plants (Nicotiana benthamiana, cucumber, melon and squash) through agro-inoculation procedures.

Project Title: O-Methylation of Sugar Residues in the Formation of Plant Cell Wall Polymers
Funding: None at present other than UCR AES Mission Funding Program
Project Description: This project is focused on elucidating the mechanism of certain steps in the synthesis of plant cell wall polymers. Specifically, the purpose is to find genes that encode enzymes that attach O-methyl ether groups to certain sugars in cell wall polysaccharides. The model system for this work is the moss Physcomitrella patens, which produces 3-O-methyl rhamnosyl residues in the arabinogalactan proteins in its cell wall. The principal approach used in this research has been to make bioinformatic-based guesses for the encoding gene and then transgenically express these candidate moss genes in tobacco. Thus far, this approach has not identified the target rhamnosyl 3-O-methyltransferase but has identified two moss genes that encode galactosyl 3-O-methyltransferases which produce 3-O-methyl galactosyl residues in the cell walls of the transgenic tobacco. Principal focus is now on characterizing these galactosyl 3-O-methyltransferases, while still attempting to identify the rhamnosyl 3-O-methyltransferase. In addition to continuing study of the transgenic tobacco plants, further information on the function of genes will be sought by knocking out the genes in the moss. Knowledge gained about the moss genes and enzymes may lead to future progress on other O-methyltransferases in higher plants with the goal of developing cell wall materials with improved properties for biofuels production.
Project Objectives: The work with biohazardous materials in this project falls in the category of recombinant DNA. The specific objectives of this project are: (1) Identify the gene that encodes an O-methyltransferase that produces 3-O-methyl rhamnosyl residues in the arabinogalactan proteins of the moss Physcomitrella patens. (2) Test the hypothesis that the two galactosyl 3-O-methyltransferases thus far identified are dual function enzymes that can produce either 3-O-methyl galactosyl residues or 3-O-methyl rhamnosyl residues, depending upon substrates and conditions. (3) Generate, and characterize the cell wall properties of, transgenic Nicotiana tabacum plants that express Physcomitrella cell wall methyltransferases. (4) Generate, and characterize the cell wall properties of, Physcomitrella plants in which cell wall methyltransferase genes have been knocked out, or disabled. (5) Use the Physcomitrella cell wall methyltransferase sequences as probes in bioinformatic searches to find other cell wall methyltransferases in model angiosperms. in seed crops that produce considerable residual biomass, such as maize, wheat, barley, sorghum, rice, and other cereals. and in proposed bioenergy crops that produce high biomass yield such as Populus, switchgrass, and Miscanthus. Note that the project proposes only bioinformatic work on the species listed in specific objective (5). The recombinant DNA work on plant species in the project involves only Physcomitrella patens and Nicotiana tabacum.

Project Title: Analyzing the Role of Yeast Telomere Capping Proteins in Coordinating Terminal Replication
Project Description: Telomeres are the termini of linear eukaryotic chromosomes. they are composed of short, repetitive GT/CA sequence tracts that are complexed into a unique chromatin structure. This structure is thought to allow telomeres to act as chromosome caps that maintain genomic stability by protecting chromosome ends from degradation and inappropriate recombination events. Consistent with this idea, disruption of telomere function correlates with increased incidence of tumor formation in mice and the formation of gross chromosomal rearrangements. Our long-term objective is to understand the processes critical throughout the cell cycle for maintaining the capping function of telomeres. The goal of this proposal is to understand the function of a set of genes, CDC13, STN1, and TEN1, which are critical for maintaining telomere integrity in S. cerevisiae. The prevailing model for the function of CDC13 is that it acts as a physical cap, preventing nucleolytic degradation of one DNA strand by binding specifically to terminal single-stranded sequences at telomeres. However, an alternate model that this proposal examines is that CDC13 primarily functions to promote complete replication of terminal DNA sequences. The lab is testing the hypothesis that Cdc13p, Stn1p, and Ten1p form a multi-protein complex that is required to promote replication of telomeres by both conventional polymerases and telomerase. Biochemical, molecular and genetic strategies will be used to examine the combined and individual contributions of CDC13, STN1, and TEN1 to maintenance of chromosome stability. The results of this investigation will contribute to understanding how chromosome end replication and protection are coordinated throughout the cell cycle. Current efforts include a focus on how these telomere proteins are regulating DNA replication more globally.

Project Description: The long term goal of this project is to elucidate the molecular mechanism of tissue-specific gene expression. HNF4a has been linked to several human diseases including hemophilia, diabetes, atherosclerosis and cancer via regulation of hepatitis B viral genes and P450 (cyp) genes. HNF4a is also known to be an essential gene in organisms ranging from insect to man and to be essential for the adult liver phenotype. Despite the obvious importance of HNF4a, much remains to be elucidated about its mechanism of action. To address this, our lab studies various aspects of HNF4-related biology, including interacting proteins, post-translational modifications and responses to environmental signals, ligand and target genes. HNF4a is a member of the superfamily of ligand-dependent transcription factors (nuclear receptors). It interacts with several other receptors and regulates the expression of others.  A related project in the lab deals with other nuclear receptors with which we define their DNA binding specificity and target genes. Those receptors are expressed in Cos7 cells and the proteins are extracted and analyzed. Mouse tissues and human cell lines expressing endogenous nuclear receptors are also used.
Project Objectives: To study the mechanism by which the liver-enriched transcription factor HNF4 regulates gene expression. We analyze lipophilic compounds such as fatty acids that bind HNF4, interacting proteins and phosphorylation of HNF4.We also identify the genes that are regulated by HNF4a and the proteins that regulate HNF4a function. To accomplish this we routinely transfect HNF4 and other cDNAs in mammalian and/or insect cell lines and transform HNF4 and other cDNAs in bacteria for expression of protein. We use recombinant adenovirus and lentivirus to express nuclear receptors and other factors in cell lines that are difficult to transfect with plasmids. We inject tumor cells into mice in order to elucidate mechanisms of tumorigenesis. Some of the cell lines we will be injecting will be stably transfected cells in which we are expressing various versions of HNF4 and the Src tyrosine kinase. We will also be looking at the actions of other nuclear receptors by treating animals with their ligands (e.g., dexamethasone for glucocorticoid receptor)and examining changes in gene expression in relevant organs.
Special Equipment Desc: We do the work with tissue culture in Biological Safety Cabinets. For routine tissue culture work we use disposable lab coats and gloves. For Adenovirus and lentivirus experiments we use gloves, goggles and disposable lab coats. We will disinfect all non metal equipment and instruments that come in contact with the adenovirus or lentivirus with a solution of 10% bleach or a pharmicidal reagent composed of quartenary benzylammonium compounds. For metal surfaces such as stainless steel hoods the pharmicidal reagent composed of quartenary benzylammonium compounds (available from Pharmacia) will be used. From the MSDS: "It offers a wider spectrum "percentage-kill-ratio" of enveloped and non-enveloped viruses, gram- positive, gram-negative and acid-fast bacteria (as well as spore-forming bacteria) and is effective as well against as fungi (yeasts, mildew, molds) and its spores. It prevents the growth and contamination of Mycoplasma spp. and is effective against a vast array of viruses including HIV and Hepatitis B." UV irradiation for at least 20 minutes after each use of the hood will also be used. We will double bag all materials that are autoclaved and disinfect the exterior of the autoclaved bag with bleach before disposal. We will use a biosafety cabinet with a UV light.

Project Title: Structure-function investigation of macromolecules involved in gene regulation
Project Description: This projects investigates molecular mechanisms underlying gene regulation. The proteins that play key role in these processes will be expressed using recombinant DNA technology in E. Coli cells and purified through standard chromatography approach. The purified protein sample is then subject to structural investigation by X-ray crystallography and NMR spectroscopy methods.
Project Objectives: 1. PCR amplication of gene products from cDNA clones obtained from commerical or academic sources. 2. Subclone the DNA fragments into the overexpression vector. 3. Express the recombinant protein using heterologous hosts such as E. Coli.

Project Title: Genetic control of plant architecture
Project Description: This research focuses on understanding the developmental role of several families of plant transcription factors (TFs) that regulate various aspects of shoot architecture. Specific aspects of shoot architecture that we are interested in include meristem formation and maintenance, axillary branching, leaf shape, and leaf angle. Our research addresses the biological role of these TFs and the function of genes regulated by them. Physiological processes that are regulated by these TFs include the phytohormone brassinosteroid and light signaling. We work in Arabidopsis, maize and rice, and cowpea. We may use Nicotiana benthamiana for transient expression studies. We may work in tomato, Brachypodium distachyon, or other plants in the future.
Project Objectives: We will generate transgenic Arabidopsis plants that express either a wild type protein or a "dominant negative" protein (made by fusion to a strong transcriptional activation or repression domain), or a reporter gene under control of the ethanol inducible alcR transcription factor. Transgenic plants containing promoters of individual transcription factors (TFs) fused to either the GUS or GFP reporter gene will be generated. Downstream targets that are regulated by individual TFs are being identified and characterized. Transgenic rice plants that express enzymes that degrade brassinosteroid hormones, under a promoter that drives expression in the blade-sheath boundary have been generated to test the hypothesis that we can manipulate leaf angle by altering local brassinosteroid accumulation. We will use CRISPR-Cas9 for gene editiing to create targeted mutations in rice, Arabidopsis, and cowpea.
Special Equipment Desc: Standard PPE: gloves, goggles, and lab coat

Project Title: Fertility, Smoking and Early Mammalian Development
Funding: TRDRP (Tobacco Related Disease Research Program, NIH
Project Description: We propose to isolate and identify the toxicants in smoke and electronic cigarette aerosol that impair normal embryonic survival and development. Once the dominant toxicants are identified,we will conduct dose response experiments with individual toxicants to determine which are most detrimental. We will also determine at what concentration each toxicant produces an effect. We will also use human embryonic stem cells to develop assays to evaluate the toxicity of cigarette smoke on mouse and human embryonic stem cell growth and differentiation. Work with human subjects will involve collecting electronic cigarette aerosol exhalation for analysis of chemical exposure related to the use of these devices. The specific aim of this project is to derive human embryonic stem cells (HESCs) at earlier stages of development, then the currently existing HESCs, which have been derived from the internal cell mass (ICM) of the blastocysts. Currently existing HESCs are already primed to differentiate to a particular lineage. (They are called primed HESCs.) This impedes the use of existing HESCs for consistent differentiation to lineages of all three germ layers (endoderm, mesoderm and ectoderm). In addition, it increases the cost for establishing a specific differentiation protocols for each line. Our goal is to isolate naïve (ground state) pluripotent stem cells that could show uniform propensity for differentiation to all tree germ layers. Each year a graduate student level class will be taught in culturing of pluripotent stem cell lines. Viruses (third generation lentiviruses) will be used to transfect cultured cells with various reporters. Addgene names are #12251 (packaging vector). Addgene #19319 (transfer vector) and Addgene # 12259 (envelope vector). Rev vector Addgene # 12253.
Project Objectives: The objective is to determine which genes are up or down regulated in cultured cells during exposure to cigarette smoke/aerosol. Specifically, we will grow hESC in culture and test tobacco constituents on their growth, survial and differentiation. We will also make transgenic stem cells using reporter genes that will enable us to follow in vitro differentiation . Existing (primed) HESC lines contribute only to the three germ layers and they DO NOT contribute to the placenta. We will also isolate HESCs that contribute to all three germ layers AND the placenta. Those cells may show characteristics of human totipotent cells, which so far have not been isolated. Although induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSC) have emerged as a replacement of the HESCs, more research is needed in terms of:  their cell origin (somatic cells or adult stem/progenitor cells of the tissue of derivation).  reprogramming.  potential tumorigenicity.  iPSC-line to line response and efficiency of differentiation. A better understanding of pluripotency, reprogramming and the signals for commitment to differentiation requires more research. Therefore the derivation of more stable naïve HESC lines is important at this stage of human embryonic stem cell research for the development of safe application of stem cells to the patients bed site. The virally transfected cells will be used to monitor various reporters that deal with cell health and oxidative/metal stress.
Special Equipment Desc: Human derived materials and viruses will be handled in a bio-safety cabinet. Personnel with have gloves, coats and masks.

Project Title: Detection and Characterization of Citrus and other plants Pathogens
Project Description: -Biological detection and characterization of citrus pathogens by inoculation of selected plant indicators -Molecular characterization and detection of viral, bacterial, bacterial like, and fungal pathogens by nucleic acid extraction in vitro amplification, cloning, sequencing and in silico analysis -Serological characterization and production of specific antibodies -Molecular and Culture-Based assessment and characterization of microbiome associated with plants
Project Objectives: Combination of the above technologies for the development of diagnostic protocols for use in the UCR California Citrus Clonal Protection Program and the citrus industry of the State as well as the Citrus Centers of the National Clean Plant Network.

Project Title: Mechanisms of Developmental Toxicity in Zebrafish Embryos. Funding agencies: National Institutes of Health (R01ES027576)
Funding: Start-up funds. National Institutes of Health
Project Description: The main objective of our research is to better understand the mechanisms of developmental toxicity for understudied chemicals currently in commerce. Our general strategy is to use high-content, phenotype-based approaches to screen and prioritize further, hypothesis-driven studies that elucidate mechanisms of chemically-induced toxicity during embryogenesis. This strategy allows us to (1) reveal novel mechanisms of toxicity for understudied chemicals -- such as those regulated under the Toxic Substances Control Act -- that are manufactured and used in high volumes within the United States. and (2) provide meaningful information for the US Environmental Protection Agency and National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (within the National Institutes of Health) when assessing the potential human health and ecological risks of chemicals in commerce.
Project Objectives: Previously approved procedure: Newly fertilized (one-to-four-cell stage) wild-type (5D) will be microinjected with control or zebrafish-specific morpholinos using using our motorized Eppendorf Injectman NI2 and FemtoJet 4X. We no longer rear nor breed fli1:egfp fish. Previously approved procedures to support triphenyl phosphate (TPP) studies within R01ES027576 - Specific Aim 2, Sub-Aim 3: Using HEK93 cells, we will rely on electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSAs) and RAR element (RARE) reporter assays to test the hypothesis that TPP-induced activation of PPARg leads to increased recruitment of RXRa from RARa to PPARg and, as a result, decreased RAR-mediated transcription. Previously approved procedures to support studies within R01ES027576 - Specific Aim 2, Sub-Aim 1: Using CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing, our original objective was to develop a stable transgenic reporter zebrafish line that allows us to identify potential PPARg ligands in vivo. Unfortunately, development of this line was unsuccessful despite repeated attempts. Therefore, we are no longer pursuing Specific Aim 2, Sub-Aim 1 as originally proposed. New procedures to support triphenyl phosphate (TPP) studies within R01ES027576 - Specific Aim 2, Sub-Aim 4: We will rely on chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq), mRNA-seq, and pparg-specific siRNA to test the hypothesis that TPP-induced toxicity is associated with PPARg-mediated effects on the transcriptome. As ChIP-grade antibodies specific to zebrafish PPARg are no longer available, we will use HepG2 cells (ATCC) as an alternative model system, as 1) the baseline transcription of pparg within HepG2 cells is elevated and 2) ChIP-grade antibodies specific to human PPARg are readily available.

Project Title: Interactive kinetics of bacteria and bacterial spores with fluorescent labels
Funding: Myriad Applied Technologies, "Bacterial Detection: Optical Methods, Devices, and Applications"
Project Description: Grow strains of a series of gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria and conduct imaging spectroscopic measurments on their interaction with chemically treated glass surfaces and ionic fluorophores.
Project Objectives: 1. Understand how the various fluorescent markers interact with the different types of bacteria For typical spectroscopic measurements: 2 - 3 mL bacterial suspension (10^3 to 10^5 cells/mL) will be sealed in disposable fluorescence (four polished sides) cuvettes. Once placed in the spectrometer, controlled amounts of dye solution will be injected through the septa. After the measurements the sample solution, the cuvette and the septa will be treated with disinfectants and disposed. 2. Test bacterial adhesion to surfaces of glass microscopic slides that chemically modify with different organic layers. For typical microscope measurements: 5 to 10 microliters of bacterial suspension (10^3 to 10^5 cells/mL) will be placed in a microwell fabricated by sealing a perforated PDMS slop on a microscope glass slide. After 1 to 5 min, the liquid will be removed and disposed in disinfectant, and the well will be washed with buffer. Through the process, the glass slide will be imaged to test the number of bacteria (per unit area) that adhere to the glass surface before the wash and remain after the wash. If needed for visualization, 1 to 2 microliters of dye solution will be added, The well will be kept covered between washes and additions. The wash solutions and all liquids removed from the wells will be disposed in disinfectant. After the experiment the microscope slides, the PDMS slobs and the cover slips will be soaked in disinfectants and disposed.

Project Title: Prolactin in health and disease
Funding: NIH, DOD, CBCRP, CRCC, COR funding, REDPOC,
IRB (human subjects): Hs-05-108 11/7/2017 HS 09-04610/272017 plus exempt status for cell line studies
Project Description: We are investigating the role of various receptors, transcription factors and signaling molecules in prolactin regulation of the growth of human breast and prostate cancer. This involves cloning of genes, the transfection of plasmid vectors into mammalian cells, sometimes the production of stable cell lines and sometimes the generation of hybrid molecules (e.g a receptor linked to green fluorescent protein).We also make recombinant proteins in bacteria, yeast and mammalian cells
Project Objectives: To understand how prolactin promotes the growth of breast and prostate cancer and how molecules we have developed (S179D prolactin and splice modulating oligomers) promote the death of tumors arising from breast and prostate cancer.

Funding: NSF REU Site:Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Plant Cell Biology. NSF EAGER grant. Gates Foundation Grant. IOS EDGE grant (submission Sept 2017). USDA-NIFA (submission 7/2017)

To determine the role of these proteins in plant defense and development. To determine insect responses to different plant defense environments. To develop protocols for Bemisia tabaci B transformation in collaboration with the Atkinson lab.

Project Title: Posttranslational regulations of proteins and CRISPR-Cas9 for genome engineering
Funding: The National Institute of Health and California Tobacco-Related Disease Research Program
Project Description: Project 1: The purpose is to isolate the high-mobility group proteins and other proteins, from human breast cancer tissues, control normal breast tissues, and cultured human cells. The isolated proteins will be characterized by mass spectrometry, with the goal to determine whether the post-translational modifications of these proteins can serve as molecular biomarkers for cancer diagnosis. We will also examine the post-translational modifications of DNMT1, eIF5A, and chromosomal proteins including histones and HMG proteins. Plasmids for the expression of these proteins will be constructed to allow for the ectoptic expression of these and related proteins. Moreover, site-directed mutagenesis will be used to construct vectors allowing for the expression of the mutated versions of these proteins. Project 2-4: The goals of these projects are to understand how DNA adducts perturb the efficiency and fidelity of DNA replication in cells. To this end, we need to construct plasmid DNA containing a site-specifically introduced DNA adduct and allow these plasmid DNA to replication in cultured human cells (which include Hela, MCF-7, 293T, Jurkat-T, HCT-116, XPV) and mouse embryonic cells that are proficient in translesion synthesis or deficient in translesion synthesis DNA polymerases including pol eta, pol iota, pol kappa, Rev1, and Rev3. For studies in human cells, siRNA techniques will also be used to knock down the expression of the above-described translesion synthesis DNA polymerases. In the last project, we will also use CRISPR-Cas9 to knock out those genes that are involved in translesion DNA synthesis, DNA repair and epigenetic modifications in cultured human cells. We will also employ the CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing method to introduce FLAG and other affinity tags to endogenous loci of the aforementioned genes, which will allow us to pull-down the proteins encoded by those genes for the subsequent mass spectrometric studies.
Project Objectives: The purpose of this project is to to determine whether the post-translational modifications of these proteins can serve as molecular biomarkers for cancer diagnosis. Another objective is to explore the molecular mechanisms of translesion synthesis, DNA repair, and epigenetic modifications.
